text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ________________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Ten miles of the hamlet. Eleven families lived East of Saskatoon all within two miles of the hamlet. How many of these were bachelor's homes? Two.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Very seldom.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday was a visiting day with some. If I had family work out, it was to church service.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Both.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the early years the meal was more often than the social feature. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? When visits were made invitation to eat meal were always made.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Put your horses in and stay for dinner.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? There was no temperance policy in Saskatoon. It was known as the Temperance Colony.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? — According to circumstances.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? The general rule.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. As underlined above and sometimes feeding for a sick farmer.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Only in winter of weather permitted.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors' houses?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days? Usually house-calling day with some, or family members, or household owner.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

That time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? What was the reason for the visit?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal handled when people had come unexpectedly?

(That is, did you ever have "tea" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or others such activity?)

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the guests were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in house? Describe.

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

School houses were used for social gatherings, fall fairs, floral shows, and meetings for many years.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? The first in Substation date unknown.

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?).

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Stabled mostly. Several families went with one team.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? Yes

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Never played cards.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc.

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls referred to in question 9, did the entire family attend?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

In summer time occasions picnics which horse racing sometimes were held. Running jumping wrestling

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized.

In 1903 Manipulation of prices, grades and weights in sale of wheat oats.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. That attitude at formally or "snark," do you remember in small town, such as gloves and hate when calling, calling out, visiting, treated cowardly in parish, etc.? 

13. Was the obverse known in your community? 

14. Describe any other details of starting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any plans or amendments not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate date whenever you can when some change in summer and fall occurred, which has been noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community—local?

Tell when it was organized, and what stage led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it all.

How often did it meet? In the fall?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? 

When was it organized? 

Approximately how many women belonged to it? 

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Concerts, tea parties and begging.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? School houses if built. Open air in summer

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? None prior to 1900

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

In 1896 Sir Wilfrid Laurier came here, to his constituency of Prince Albert, and spoke to the few assembled from the railway coach platform at Saskatoon. He said he was sure the Liberal party would win (it did) and he was going to "skin the Tory bear of protection," the Tory Bear Full boards.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumblety peg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1934, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, purpose, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it lasted long or not.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, where? Who gave them? What were the topics? How often were they held? How long did they last? Who attended? What was the purpose of these lectures?

21. What games did boys play in summer? (Skipping rope, marbles, etc.)

22. What games did girls play in summer? (Skipping rope, play house, etc.)
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
A good deal of card playing in winter.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
Children did skating where possible. Tobogganing was popular.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophors or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
Snowballing and creating snowmen - weather allowing.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
Give year and month if possible. Sunday School picnic at the city farm. Think 1894.

26. Who organized it?  
Everybody invited to A.S. picnic.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? Everybody invited.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
Ball games, racing horses, running, jumping and baseball.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Everybody contributed food and sat on the ground in a circle for the tea or lunch.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Meat sandwiches, coffee tea.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? Afternoon 3 pm - 6 or 7 pm.
22. What winter games were played outdoors - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families," "Whistors," or others; checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

23. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Give year and month if possible.

Who organized it?

Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

What did you have to eat and drink? Meal furnished by the office of the town council.

What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). Football, baseball, wrestling

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
23. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of places which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community places, school, or Sunday School, places, parks, picnic grounds, etc., tell about any differences in members attending, what kind of food was served, what hall, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in places since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (boys, women, mostly).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? July 1st was always observed by short visitation weeks before 1922. Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

A Bible with commentary by Robert Smith. Chamber's Encyclopedia. Had a shelf of other books—titles and authors forgotten.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Loans and exchanges were made. All our smaller books were loaned.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? A school library was established at Evansdale School in 1873.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Yes—a common practice.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? (Give date.)

41. Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? (What month, or any special day, such as July 4th or July 1st.)

42. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

44. What kind of books and how many?

45. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

46. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

47. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

48. Was there a school library?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? The had in our family The Montreal Witness and Northern Messenger which we regularly loaned to neighbors.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others. The Montreal Witness stopped publication when John Douglas died - date unknown.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   The Bible with Commentary, Encyclopedia, a Bible of my father from Wales, Sunday's Hymns, Presbyterian hymnal book, Anglican Com. Paper and Hymn book.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. - No, The Montreal Witness was a library in itself. The Phoenix was first published about 1902 or '03. We always took the Phoenix until it was merged with the Star.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? The names of the periodicals subscribed to are:

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling how you added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? None

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Mrs. Stephenson had an organ.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. An organ in 1905. A piano in 1930 bought in Saskatoon—Alwood Richie.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. Hymns and songs were used at all entertainments. The song leader was Mr. Clement who was our next neighbor on the farm. He was a brother of Justice Pope Clement of Vancouver.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. Hymns, children's school songs were sung.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? "Jingle Bell," "Sleep, Baby, Sleep," "Canada," "Maple Leaf Forever," "God Save the King."

in the community? As above.

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. No. I came from Wales where Choral Singing was popular in Welsh and English.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? Not until 1910. Who started it? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have when you arrived?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? (List dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.)

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the homes? (List titles.)

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or take up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? Who started it? How long did it continue? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

My two daughters became church organists.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? No

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

My wife and I hang out a great deal publicly and at home. We became somewhat of politicians doing a good deal of speaking. Represented the town in parliament 1921-1925 and the constituency of Portown from 1925-1930.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? Not now.

Thirty years ago we had 30 children in the Evansdale School—now it is closed; there are no children in the community.

General

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is there any important or missing information in your community not yet included with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests:

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, etc.? Mention their name.

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading clubs, etc., not already mentioned.

(use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)
Oxford
No. 613 S

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
